importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the Tel Aviv soccer derby cancellation due to violent riots, highlighting a significant public safety event in Israel.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The time of the article's update, indicating when the latest developments and official statements about the match cancellation were reported.

keyTakeAways: The Tel Aviv soccer derby between Hapoel and Maccabi was canceled due to violent riots and public disorder, with injuries to 12 civilians and three police officers.
Police cited the endangerment of human life as the reason for canceling the match, citing pyrotechnics and smoke grenades thrown from the stands.
Hapoel criticized the police response, accusing them of preparing for a war instead of a sporting event and claiming they took control of the sport.
The incident follows a similar ban of Maccabi fans from attending a Europa League match in England due to security concerns, prompting political and community backlash.
UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer condemned the English police ban, stating it was 'wrong' and emphasized the need for all fans to enjoy sports without fear.
The UK government acknowledged the concerns raised by Israeli authorities and has initiated dialogue with Israeli police regarding the Tel Aviv incident.
Maccabi fans had previously been involved in violent scenes during a match against Ajax in Amsterdam, indicating a pattern of security-related incidents.

namedEntities.name: Tel Aviv
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A city in Israel, site of the soccer derby between Hapoel and Maccabi.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The location of the derby match, central to the incident involving violent fan behavior and police intervention.

namedEntities.name: Hapoel
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A football club based in Tel Aviv, one of the rivals in the derby.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Hapoel is directly involved in the conflict, criticizing police actions and expressing concerns over the cancellation of the match.

namedEntities.name: Maccabi
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A football club based in Tel Aviv, the rival of Hapoel in the derby.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Maccabi is the other side in the derby; although it did not comment, its fans were involved in the violent scenes, and the match was canceled due to fan unrest.

namedEntities.name: Bloomfield Stadium
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A shared stadium in Tel Aviv used for the derby match.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The venue where the match was supposed to take place, and where fan clashes and police intervention occurred.

namedEntities.name: Israel Police
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The law enforcement agency in Israel responsible for public order.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: They canceled the match due to public disorder, injured civilians and officers, and faced criticism for their response.

namedEntities.name: West Midlands Police
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The law enforcement agency in England responsible for security decisions regarding sports events.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: They banned Maccabi fans from a Europa League match in England, reflecting broader security concerns about fan behavior in international events.

namedEntities.name: Aston Villa
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An English football club in the Premier League.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The venue where the Europa League match involving Maccabi fans was scheduled, linking the security issue to a UK-based match.

namedEntities.name: Ajax
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Maccabi fans were previously involved in violent incidents during a match against Ajax in Amsterdam, showing a pattern of fan-related violence.

namedEntities.name: Keir Starmer
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The Prime Minister of the United Kingdom.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He criticized the UK police ban on Maccabi fans, emphasizing the importance of fan safety and inclusivity in sports.

namedEntities.name: CNN
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The source reporting on the incident, contributing to international awareness of the Tel Aviv derby cancellation and related security issues.

namedEntities.name: European football
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A broad category of international football matches including leagues and tournaments.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The context of previous fan bans in Europe, indicating a wider trend of security concerns affecting international football events.

namedEntities.name: Premier League
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The top-tier football league in England.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The league in which the Israeli Premier League and European matches are compared, highlighting cross-national security concerns.

namedEntities.name: Europa League
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The match where Maccabi fans were banned in England, illustrating international security policies affecting fan attendance.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The Tel Aviv soccer derby between Hapoel and Maccabi was canceled after violent riots and public disorder at Bloomfield Stadium, with 12 civilians and three police officers injured. Police cited the endangerment of human life due to pyrotechnics and smoke grenades thrown by fans as the reason for cancellation. Hapoel criticized the police response, accusing them of overreacting and taking control of the sport. This incident follows a similar ban of Maccabi fans from a Europa League match in England due to security concerns, prompting criticism from UK leaders including Prime Minister Keir Starmer, who emphasized the need for safe and inclusive fan experiences. The UK government has since engaged with Israeli authorities to understand the events in Tel Aviv, recognizing the broader issue of fan violence and security in international football.
title: Tel Aviv Soccer Derby Canceled by Police Due to 'Violent Riots'
